  • Winder: Linking Speech and Visual Objects to Support Communication in Asynchronous Collaboration

    Tipo do item Conferência
    Autor Tae Soo Kim
    Autor Seungsu Kim
    Autor Yoonseo Choi
    Autor Juho Kim
    Resumo Team members commonly collaborate on visual documents remotely and asynchronously. Particularly, students are frequently restricted to this setting as they often do not share work schedules or physical workspaces. As communication in this setting has delays and limits the main modality to text, members exert more effort to reference document objects and understand others’ intentions. We propose Winder, a Figma plugin that addresses these challenges through linked tapes—multimodal comments of clicks and voice. Bidirectional links between the clicked-on objects and voice recordings facilitate understanding tapes: selecting objects retrieves relevant recordings, and playing recordings highlights related objects. By periodically prompting users to produce tapes, Winder preemptively obtains information to satisfy potential communication needs. Through a five-day study with eight teams of three, we evaluated the system’s impact on teams asynchronously designing graphical user interfaces. Our findings revealed that producing linked tapes could be as lightweight as face-to-face (F2F) interactions while transmitting intentions more precisely than text. Furthermore, with preempted tapes, teammates coordinated tasks and invited members to build on each others’ work.
    Data 2021
    URL https://doi.org/10.1145/3411764.3445686
    Extra event-place: Yokohama, Japan
    Lugar New York, NY, USA
    Editor Association for Computing Machinery
    ISBN 978-1-4503-8096-6
    Série CHI '21
    Título dos anais Proceedings of the 2021 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
    DOI 10.1145/3411764.3445686
    Data de adição 15/10/2023 11:00:02
    Data de modificação 13/11/2023 12:58:00

    Etiquetas:

    • ACM
    • Asynchronous Communication
    • Leitura Inicial - DESCARTADO
    • Multimodal Input
    • Speech
    • Team Collaboration
    • User Interface Design.
    • Visual Document
    • Voice

    Notas:

    • #nota

      Não é um artigo da área de ESS ou revisão secundária.

    • #resumo

      Team members commonly collaborate on visual documents remotely and asynchronously. Particularly, students are frequently restricted to this setting as they often do not share work schedules or physical workspaces. As communication in this setting has delays and limits the main modality to text, members exert more effort to reference document objects and understand others’ intentions. We propose Winder, a Figma plugin that addresses these challenges through linked tapes—multimodal comments of clicks and voice. Bidirectional links between the clicked-on objects and voice recordings facilitate understanding tapes: selecting objects retrieves relevant recordings, and playing recordings highlights related objects. By periodically prompting users to produce tapes, Winder preemptively obtains information to satisfy potential communication needs. Through a five-day study with eight teams of three, we evaluated the system’s impact on teams asynchronously designing graphical user interfaces. Our findings revealed that producing linked tapes could be as lightweight as face-to-face (F2F) interactions while transmitting intentions more precisely than text. Furthermore, with preempted tapes, teammates coordinated tasks and invited members to build on each others’ work.

  • Zeno: An Interactive Framework for Behavioral Evaluation of Machine Learning

    Tipo do item Conferência
    Autor Ángel Alexander Cabrera
    Autor Erica Fu
    Autor Donald Bertucci
    Autor Kenneth Holstein
    Autor Ameet Talwalkar
    Autor Jason I. Hong
    Autor Adam Perer
    Resumo Machine learning models with high accuracy on test data can still produce systematic failures, such as harmful biases and safety issues, when deployed in the real world. To detect and mitigate such failures, practitioners run behavioral evaluation of their models, checking model outputs for specific types of inputs. Behavioral evaluation is important but challenging, requiring that practitioners discover real-world patterns and validate systematic failures. We conducted 18 semi-structured interviews with ML practitioners to better understand the challenges of behavioral evaluation and found that it is a collaborative, use-case-first process that is not adequately supported by existing task- and domain-specific tools. Using these findings, we designed zeno, a general-purpose framework for visualizing and testing AI systems across diverse use cases. In four case studies with participants using zeno on real-world models, we found that practitioners were able to reproduce previous manual analyses and discover new systematic failures.
    Data 2023
    URL https://doi.org/10.1145/3544548.3581268
    Extra event-place: Hamburg, Germany
    Lugar New York, NY, USA
    Editor Association for Computing Machinery
    ISBN 978-1-4503-9421-5
    Série CHI '23
    Título dos anais Proceedings of the 2023 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
    DOI 10.1145/3544548.3581268
    Data de adição 15/10/2023 11:00:13
    Data de modificação 13/11/2023 09:59:51

    Etiquetas:

    • Leitura Inicial - DESCARTADO

    Notas:

    • #nota

      Não é um artigo da área de ESS ou revisão secundária.

    • #resumo

      Machine learning models with high accuracy on test data can still produce systematic failures, such as harmful biases and safety issues, when deployed in the real world. To detect and mitigate such failures, practitioners run behavioral evaluation of their models, checking model outputs for specific types of inputs. Behavioral evaluation is important but challenging, requiring that practitioners discover real-world patterns and validate systematic failures. We conducted 18 semi-structured interviews with ML practitioners to better understand the challenges of behavioral evaluation and found that it is a collaborative, use-case-first process that is not adequately supported by existing task- and domain-specific tools. Using these findings, we designed zeno, a general-purpose framework for visualizing and testing AI systems across diverse use cases. In four case studies with participants using zeno on real-world models, we found that practitioners were able to reproduce previous manual analyses and discover new systematic failures.
